title: CPU, Memory and Program Execution
description: Test your knowledge on CPU, Memory and Program Execution!

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT one of the five basic parts of a computer system?
What does CPU stand for?
Which part of the CPU performs arithmetic and logical operations?
What is the main function of the Control Unit in the CPU?
What does RAM stand for?
What does the term "random access" in Random Access Memory (RAM) mean?

answers.text: The ability to access memory locations in any order
The ability to store data permanently
The ability to access data sequentially

questions.text: What is the primary function of cache memory?

answers.text: Store temporary data during program execution
Speed up access to frequently used data

questions.text: What is the first step in the Fetch/Execute cycle?
What does the CPU do during the "Fetch" step?

answers.text: Performs the operation defined by the instruction
Writes the result to memory or a register

questions.text: In the machine cycle what happens during the "Decode" step?

answers.text: The CPU retrieves an instruction from memory
The instruction is translated into signals
The result is stored in memory

questions.text: What is the purpose of the Program Counter (PC) in the CPU?

answers.text: To store the address of the next instruction to be executed
To count the number of instructions executed
To manage the flow of data between registers

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the concept of virtual memory?

answers.text: Using secondary storage as an extension of RAM
Increasing the physical size of RAM
Storing frequently accessed data in the CPU cache
Encrypting data in RAM for security

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the property of memory addresses in a computer system?

answers.text: They are sequential and start at 1
They are sequential and start at 0
They are non-sequential and start at 1
They are non-sequential and start at 0

questions.text: Which of the following operations is NOT typically performed by the ALU?
What is the primary function of the input unit in a computer system?
Which of the following is considered a peripheral device
What happens when data does not "fit" in the finite capacity of a memory location?

answers.text: Data is stored in the next available location

questions.text: What happens during the "Execute" step of the instruction cycle?

answers.text: The instruction is fetched from memory
The instruction is translated into machine code
The CPU carries out the operations specified by the instruction
The result of the instruction is written back to memory or a register

questions.text: Which of the following best describes an interrupt in the context of program execution?

answers.text: A mechanism to handle errors in program execution
A signal that temporarily halts the CPU to prioritize a different task
A method to speed up the execution of instructions
A technique to optimize memory usage

questions.text: In the Instruction Fetch (IF) phase, where is the instruction moved to?
In the instruction "ADD 4000, 2000, 2080", what does the control unit do after decoding this instruction?

answers.text: Adds the values in memory locations 2000 and 2080, and stores the result in the ALU
Retrieves the data from memory locations 2000 and 2080, performs the addition, and stores the result in memory location 4000
Fetches the instruction from memory location 4000, decodes it, and adds the values
Stores the sum of the values in memory locations 2000 and 2080 in memory location 4000

questions.text: What is the significance of the finite capacity of memory locations?

answers.text: It limits the number of instructions that can be executed by the CPU
It ensures that data can be accessed randomly
It restricts the size of data that can be stored in each location, potentially leading to data overflow
It guarantees that memory is organised in a sequence of discrete locations

questions.text: How does the concept of 'memory words' improve the efficiency of memory usage?

answers.text: By allowing multiple bytes to be accessed simultaneously
By ensuring data is stored in non-contiguous memory locations
By reducing the finite capacity limitations of individual memory locations
By enabling faster decoding of instructions

questions.text: What is the primary reason for the use of discrete locations in memory organisation?

answers.text: To enhance the speed of data retrieval
To facilitate the random access of data
To ensure each memory location has a unique address
To maximize the storage capacity of memory

questions.text: What is a key characteristic of RAM that differentiates it from other types of memory?

answers.text: It is volatile and loses its content when power is turned off
It is used primarily for input/output operations
It can only be accessed sequentially

questions.text: During the Instruction Execution (EX) phase, what happens if the ALU encounters an undefined operation?

answers.text: It skips the operation and moves to the next instruction
It raises an exception or error
It requests the control unit for further instructions

questions.text: How does the ALU handle logical operations such as AND, OR, and NOT?

answers.text: By fetching additional data from memory
By interacting with the control unit for each operation

questions.text: What would likely happen if the control unit fails to update the Program Counter (PC) after an instruction is fetched?

answers.text: The same instruction would be fetched repeatedly
The next instruction would be skipped
The ALU would perform an undefined operation
The fetched instruction would not be decoded

questions.text: In the context of computer memory, what is a primary benefit of hierarchical memory organisation?

answers.text: It reduces the complexity of the control unit
It optimizes the speed and cost of memory access
It ensures all data fits into the fastest memory available
It simplifies the process of data storage and retrieval

questions.text: What is the significance of the binary object file format?

answers.text: It allows easy modification of program instructions
It enables the computer to run software by interpreting binary instructions
It increases the readability of the program for humans
It reduces the size of the program in memory

title: Compilation Interpretation & Java Virtual Machine
description: Test your knowledge on Compilation Interpretation & Java Virtual Machine!

questions.text: What is a high-level programming language?
Which program converts assembly code to machine code?
What is the role of a linker?

answers.text: Converts source code to object code
Combines different assembled parts into a whole

questions.text: Which of the following languages is typically compiled?
What does an interpreter do?

answers.text: Converts source code to object code
Follows the source code and executes it directly
Combines different assembled parts into a whole

questions.text: What is a disadvantage of interpretation?
What does JVM stand for?
Which language does the Java compiler translate Java source code into?
What is the primary advantage of Java's bytecode?
What does JIT stand for in the context of JVM?
Which of the following is a characteristic of low-level languages?

answers.text: Easier for humans to read and write
Harder for humans to read and write

questions.text: In the compilation process, what is the role of the loader?

answers.text: Converts source code to object code
Loads the program into memory at a given location
Combines different assembled parts into a whole

questions.text: Why is compilation generally more efficient than interpretation?

answers.text: Compilation is done once for each program
Compiled programs are easier to debug

questions.text: What is cross-compilation?

answers.text: Compiler runs on the same platform as the target code
Compiler runs on a different platform than the target code
Interpreter runs on the same platform as the source code
Interpreter runs on a different platform than the source code

questions.text: Which of the following is an advantage of interpretation?
What is an intermediate language in the context of combined compilation and interpretation?

answers.text: A language between high and low level that can be efficiently interpreted

questions.text: Why is Java considered platform-independent?

answers.text: It compiles directly to machine code
It uses a single compiler for all platforms
It compiles to bytecode that can be interpreted by JVM on any platform

questions.text: What is the primary function of a virtual machine?

answers.text: To convert high-level code to machine code
To execute an instruction stream in software
To link different parts of a program

questions.text: How does JIT compilation improve performance?

answers.text: By compiling bytecode to machine code just before execution

questions.text: What is the main difference between a stack machine and a register machine?

answers.text: Stack machines use a stack for intermediate results, register machines use registers
Stack machines are faster than register machines
Register machines are used in virtual machines
Stack machines cannot handle complex expressions

questions.text: What is the primary disadvantage of using a virtual machine for program execution?

answers.text: Slower execution compared to native machine code

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the role of the Java Runtime Environment (JRE)?

answers.text: Compiles Java source code to bytecode
Executes Java bytecode using the JVM
Translates high-level Java code to machine code
Links different parts of a Java program

questions.text: Why might a JIT compiler be preferred over a traditional interpreter in certain scenarios?

answers.text: It reduces the need for platform-specific code
It compiles the entire program ahead of time
It improves execution speed by compiling code at runtime

questions.text: What is one key advantage of bytecode over directly compiling to machine code?

answers.text: Greater portability across different hardware architectures
Simpler to optimize for specific hardware features

questions.text: In the context of Java, what is the primary role of the 'javac' tool?

answers.text: Compile Java source code to bytecode

questions.text: What is a significant challenge in cross-compilation?

answers.text: Ensuring code executes correctly on the target platform

questions.text: Why is the concept of a stack important in JVM architecture?

answers.text: It provides a fixed memory allocation for variables
It supports the execution of recursive methods
It facilitates the use of global variables

questions.text: Which of the following JVM instruction groups is primarily responsible for method invocation?

answers.text: Invoking a method / return from a method

questions.text: How does the JVM ensure security during program execution?

answers.text: By limiting the use of certain instructions
By running all code in a virtual environment

questions.text: What is a key feature of the picoJava II chip in relation to JVM?

answers.text: It compiles Java code directly to machine code
It interprets Java bytecode in hardware for embedded applications
It optimizes Java code for desktop applications
It supports multiple high-level programming languages

title: Computer Organisation and Architecture
description: Test your knowledge on Computer Organisation and Architecture!

questions.text: What type of memory is commonly implemented in Dynamic RAM (DRAM)?
Which type of memory cannot be modified once it is programmed?
In the von Neumann architecture, what is stored in the instruction register?
Which I/O mechanism involves the CPU constantly checking the status of an I/O device?
What does DMA stand for?
Which type of system architecture features multiple processors sharing bus, clock, memory, and peripherals?
What is the main advantage of a symmetric multiprocessor system over an asymmetric one?
What is a common example of a multicore system?
What is the primary purpose of a device driver in a computer system?

answers.text: To provide a uniform interface to the device

questions.text: Which storage device is typically the fastest?
What is a key characteristic of Dynamic RAM (DRAM)?
What role does the device controller play in a computer system?

answers.text: It interfaces the CPU with I/O devices
It controls the execution of programs

questions.text: Which I/O mechanism is preferred for moving large amounts of data?
How does the CPU interact with main memory during execution?

answers.text: By sending and receiving data directly from the cache
By loading instructions from main memory and storing results back to it
By constantly polling the memory for updates
By using secondary storage as an intermediary

questions.text: What is the primary function of cache memory in a computer system?

answers.text: To hold frequently accessed data for quick retrieval

questions.text: What is the primary disadvantage of Programmed I/O?

answers.text: It requires the CPU to be constantly busy checking I/O status

questions.text: In a multiprocessor system, what does the term 'graceful degradation' refer to?

answers.text: The system continues to operate even if one processor fails
The system gradually slows down under heavy load
The system loses data when a processor fails

questions.text: What is the key difference between EEPROM and ROM?

answers.text: EEPROM can be electrically erased and reprogrammed
ROM is volatile while EEPROM is non-volatile
ROM is used for main memory

questions.text: Which mechanism does the CPU use to load instructions for execution?
Why are multiprocessor systems more cost-effective than single-processor systems?

answers.text: They share peripherals, storage, and power

questions.text: In the context of I/O, what does 'polling' refer to?

answers.text: The CPU continuously checks the status of an I/O device
The CPU waits for an interrupt signal from an I/O device
The I/O device sends data directly to memory
The I/O device operates independently of the CPU

questions.text: What is a key characteristic of the von Neumann architecture regarding memory operations?

answers.text: Instructions and data are stored separately
Instructions and data share the same memory space
Only data is stored in memory
Instructions are executed directly from the cache

questions.text: How does the CPU handle an interrupt signal from an I/O device?

answers.text: It immediately stops all operations and addresses the interrupt
It finishes the current instruction before handling the interrupt
It ignores the interrupt until the I/O device sends another signal
It transfers control to a device driver to handle the interrupt

questions.text: What is the primary benefit of Direct Memory Access (DMA) over other I/O mechanisms?

answers.text: It reduces the number of interrupts
It increases the speed of data transfer
It allows the CPU to focus on other tasks

questions.text: Why is secondary storage necessary in a computer system?

answers.text: Main memory is volatile and limited in size
It is faster than main memory
It provides temporary storage for programs
It is used for executing instructions

questions.text: What is the role of a device driver in the context of I/O operations?

answers.text: It directly controls the hardware devices
It translates I/O requests from the operating system into device-specific operations
It manages the CPU's interactions with memory
It handles high-speed data transfer between devices

questions.text: What is the primary advantage of a symmetric multiprocessor (SMP) system?

answers.text: It allows processors to be used equally, improving load balancing
It reduces the cost of system design
It provides better support for single-threaded applications

questions.text: In a clustered system, what does 'high-availability' refer to?

answers.text: The ability to add more storage on demand
The ability to maintain operation despite failures
The ability to perform high-speed computations
The ability to run on low power

questions.text: Why is the fetch/decode/execute cycle essential in CPU operations?

answers.text: It allows the CPU to process instructions systematically
It manages the CPU's power consumption
It speeds up the overall processing time

questions.text: What is the purpose of the stack in a CPU's architecture?

answers.text: To store frequently accessed data for quick retrieval
To manage local variables and method calls
To handle direct memory access operations

title: Application Layer:
description: Test your knowledge on the Application Layer!

questions.text: What is the highest layer in the TCP/IP stack?
Which protocol is used for web communication?
Which protocol is used for sending emails?
What is the default port number for HTTP?
What does DNS stand for?
Which architecture involves clients and servers?
What does SMTP stand for?
What type of IP address does a server in a client-server architecture usually have?
Which HTTP method is used to request data from a specified resource?
What is the main purpose of a domain name in DNS?

answers.text: To identify the MAC address of a host
To translate human-readable names into IP addresses

questions.text: Which transport protocol provides reliable data transfer for HTTP?
In a P2P architecture, how do peers typically communicate?
What is the function of a socket in network communication?

answers.text: To act as an endpoint for sending and receiving data
To translate domain names into IP addresses

questions.text: What is a common use of port 443?
Which of the following is a key characteristic of HTTP/1.1?
What is the purpose of the Mail Access Protocol?

answers.text: To send emails between mail servers
To retrieve emails from mail servers

questions.text: Which DNS record type is used to map a hostname to an IP address?
What does the 'GET' method do in an HTTP request?

answers.text: Requests data from a specified resource
Establishes a tunnel to the server

questions.text: Which protocol is primarily used for resolving domain names to IP addresses?
What is a key advantage of the P2P architecture?
How does the DNS hierarchy improve scalability and reliability?

answers.text: By centralising all DNS queries to a single server
By distributing the database across multiple servers
By using a peer-to-peer architecture for DNS resolution
By caching all DNS records on client machines

questions.text: What is the role of the authoritative DNS server?

answers.text: To store the primary DNS records for a domain
To forward DNS queries to the root DNS server
To handle local DNS queries within an ISP
To cache DNS records for faster resolution

questions.text: Which component in the email system is responsible for storing incoming messages?
What is a primary benefit of using persistent HTTP connections?

answers.text: Lower memory usage on the client side

questions.text: In the context of HTTP, what does 'stateless' mean?

answers.text: The server maintains the state of each client session
The server does not maintain any information about past client requests
The client stores all state information
The server uses cookies to track client sessions

questions.text: Why is TCP preferred over UDP for HTTP communication?

answers.text: UDP does not support large data transfers
UDP is not compatible with HTTP

questions.text: What is a significant drawback of using non-persistent HTTP connections?

answers.text: Higher latency due to multiple TCP handshakes

questions.text: Which SMTP command is used to start the transfer of the message body?
What does a Type MX DNS record specify?

answers.text: The IP address of a host
The mail server for a domain
The canonical name for an alias
The authoritative name server for a domain

questions.text: Why might an organisation prefer to use IMAP over POP3 for email retrieval?

answers.text: IMAP is more secure than POP3
IMAP keeps all messages on the server, allowing access from multiple devices
IMAP allows for better spam filtering

title: Transport Layer
description: Test your knowledge on the Transport Layer!

questions.text: What does UDP stand for?
What does TCP stand for?
Which layer provides logical communication between application processes running on different hosts?
Which transport protocol provides reliable, in-order delivery?
Which transport protocol is connectionless and provides best-effort delivery?
What is the primary purpose of a port number in networking?

answers.text: To identify the IP address of a host
To identify a specific process or service on a host

questions.text: Which protocol uses port 80 by default?
Which layer is responsible for multiplexing and demultiplexing in networking?
What is the size of the UDP header?
Which field in a TCP segment header is used to acknowledge the receipt of data?
Which transport protocol is typically used for streaming multimedia applications?
What does a TCP three-way handshake involve?
Which protocol uses the 'best effort' delivery model?
What is the primary function of the TCP flow control mechanism?

answers.text: To ensure packets arrive in order
To prevent the sender from overwhelming the receiver
To verify the integrity of data

questions.text: What is multiplexing in the context of the transport layer?

answers.text: Combining multiple data streams into one
Directing data to the correct application

questions.text: Which type of multiplexing is used by TCP?
What mechanism does UDP use to detect errors in transmitted segments?
Which field in a UDP segment helps to identify the receiving application?
How does TCP handle segment retransmission in case of packet loss?

answers.text: Using sequence numbers and acknowledgment numbers

questions.text: What is the primary difference between TCP and UDP in terms of reliability?

answers.text: TCP is reliable, UDP is not
UDP is reliable, TCP is not

questions.text: What additional mechanism does RDT 3.0 introduce to handle packet loss?
How does TCP's fast retransmit mechanism improve performance?

answers.text: By reducing the size of the segments
By retransmitting the segment before the timer expires if duplicate ACKs are received
By reducing the need for acknowledgments

questions.text: What is the purpose of the window size parameter in TCP?

answers.text: To control the flow of data

questions.text: What happens during the SYN flooding attack in the context of TCP?

answers.text: Multiple SYN requests are sent to overwhelm the server
Multiple ACKs are sent to confuse the server
Multiple FIN requests are sent to close the connection
Multiple RST requests are sent to reset the connection

questions.text: How does TCP ensure data is delivered in the correct order?
Which transport protocol is typically used for DNS queries?
What is the key difference between TCP and UDP multiplexing?

answers.text: TCP uses connection-oriented multiplexing; UDP uses connectionless multiplexing
TCP uses port numbers; UDP does not
UDP uses sequence numbers; TCP does not
TCP uses a checksum; UDP does not

questions.text: In TCP, what does the sequence number represent?

answers.text: The total number of segments sent
The byte stream number of the first byte in the segment
The port number of the destination
The total size of the segment

questions.text: Why does UDP have a smaller header size compared to TCP?

answers.text: UDP does not provide reliability, ordering, or flow control
UDP does not use port numbers
UDP does not use IP addresses

questions.text: What is the purpose of the TCP three-way handshake?

answers.text: To establish a connection and synchronize sequence numbers

title: Binary trees
description: Test your knowledge on Binary trees!

questions.text: What is a binary tree?

answers.text: A tree with each node having up to three children
A tree with each node having up to two children
A tree with each node having one child

questions.text: In a binary search tree, where are nodes with values less than the parent node placed?
Which of the following is an application of a binary search tree?
In a binary search tree, which traversal method visits nodes in sorted order?
What is the time complexity of searching in a balanced binary search tree?
Which node is the root in a binary search tree?
What is the height of a tree?

answers.text: Length of the longest path from root to a leaf

questions.text: Which traversal method visits the root node first?
What defines a balanced tree?

answers.text: All levels have the same number of nodes
The height of left and right subtrees of any node differ by at most one
The tree has no leaf nodes

questions.text: What type of tree has nodes with values only greater than the root on the right?
Which operation on a binary search tree can cause it to become unbalanced?
What is the time complexity for inserting an element into a binary search tree in the worst case?
Which case in deletion involves finding the left-most node of the right subtree?

answers.text: Deleting a node with one child
Deleting a node with two children

questions.text: In a binary search tree, which traversal method is used to get the reverse sorted order of elements?
Which tree traversal algorithm is used by search operations in a BST?
What does the leaf node of a tree signify?
What is a perfectly balanced binary tree?

answers.text: A tree where each node has the same number of children
A tree where all levels are fully filled
A tree where the height of left and right subtrees of any node differ by at most one
A tree where all leaf nodes are at the same level

questions.text: In a BST, what is the maximum number of children a node can have?
Which type of tree traversal is best suited for evaluating arithmetic expressions?
Which of the following is true for a node with two children in a BST?

answers.text: It can be deleted without reordering
Its in-order predecessor is the maximum value node in its left subtree.
Its in-order successor is the minimum value node in its right subtree
Both B and C are correct

questions.text: Which is not a valid property of a binary search tree?

answers.text: Left subtree has nodes with values less than the root
Right subtree has nodes with values greater than the root
In-order traversal gives nodes in non-decreasing order
A node with only one child has its child as a leaf node

questions.text: What is the primary advantage of using a binary search tree over a linked list?
What is the average-case time complexity for searching in a binary search tree?
In which scenario does a BST degenerate into a linked list?

answers.text: When nodes are inserted in random order
When nodes are inserted in increasing order
When nodes have only one child

questions.text: If a BST is traversed in pre-order, which of the following is true?

answers.text: Nodes are visited in sorted order
Nodes are visited level by level

questions.text: What is the time complexity of deleting a node with two children in a BST?
What distinguishes a binary search tree from other binary trees?

answers.text: Nodes can have up to two children
All nodes are connected by edges
It maintains a sorted order property

questions.text: When deleting a node with two children in a BST, which node typically replaces it?
Which of the following is a characteristic of a balanced binary search tree?

answers.text: All leaf nodes are at the same depth
The height difference between left and right subtrees is no more than one
It does not have a root node

questions.text: How does a BST handle duplicate values?

answers.text: Inserts all duplicates in the right subtree
Inserts all duplicates in the left subtree

title: Conceptual & Logical Design
description: Test your knowledge on Conceptual & Logical Design!

questions.text: What is a database?

answers.text: A large collection of persistent data

questions.text: Who invented the concept of relational databases?
Which of the following is a primary feature of a database?

answers.text: Accessible from a single application only

questions.text: What does ER stand for in ER Diagram?
What symbol is typically used to represent entities in an ER diagram?
Which SQL command is used to create a table?
What is the primary key in a table?

answers.text: A field that can be null
A field that uniquely identifies each record
A field that contains duplicate values
A field that stores primary data

questions.text: What does 'VARCHAR' stand for in SQL?
Which command is used to delete a table in SQL?
What is a 'tuple' in a relational database?
